line: Chapter 14
label: heading

line: Virtual Doppelgangers: Psychological Effects
label: heading

line: of Avatars Who Ignore Their Owners
label: heading

line: Jeremy N. Bailenson and Kathryn Y. Segovia
label: heading

line: Imagine a world where multiple versions of yourself exist. These other versions
label: paragraph

line: of you may look like you but need not behave like you. Famous authors and
label: paragraph

line: screenwriters have depicted this type of scenario multiple times in movies and
label: paragraph

line: literary works. For example, in the film Being John Malkovich, the actor
label: paragraph

line: Malkovich wakes up in a restaurant and looks across the table (Jonze 1999).
label: paragraph

line: There is a woman wearing a revealing evening dress, but as his gaze pans up, he
label: paragraph

line: is stunned to see his own head on top of the voluptuous female form. Seconds
label: paragraph

line: later, a waiter walks by and is also wearing his head. His psychological response
label: paragraph

line: is predictably dire, and the terror only increases as he pans across the room and
label: paragraph

line: realizes that every single person in the restaurant, ranging from jazz singers to
label: paragraph

line: midgets, is wearing his head. He is literally trapped in a room full of identical
label: paragraph

line: twins behaving independently of his own intentions and actions. In Edgar Allan
label: paragraph

line: Poe’s William Wilson, the main character William meets another boy who shares
label: paragraph

line: his name (Poe 1839). Throughout the story, William’s double changes to act and
label: paragraph

line: look more like William. William grows frustrated with his double who is con-
label: paragraph

line: stantly mimicking him and giving him unsolicited advice and eventually stabs his
label: paragraph

line: double to death. Additionally, in a powerful scene in William Gibson’s
label: paragraph

line: Neuromancer (1984), one of the main characters, Riviera, forces a character
label: paragraph

line: named Molly to witness a hologram of herself perform a number of unspeakable
label: paragraph

line: acts. Molly’s physical self observes the interaction, but she cannot control the
label: paragraph

line: actions of the other version of herself.
label: paragraph

line: The above scenarios may seem like situations that would only be possible in
label: paragraph

line: science fiction, but if we take a close look at today’s digital media, we find that
label: paragraph

line: virtual versions of ourselves exist in many different places.
label: paragraph

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: Stanford University
label: paragraph

line: e-mails: bailenson@gmail.com; kathrynyr@gmail.com
label: paragraph

line: W.S. Bainbridge (ed.), Online Worlds: Convergence of the Real and the Virtual, 175
label: paragraph

line: Human-Computer Interaction Series, DOI 10.1007/978-1-84882-825-4_14,
label: paragraph

line: © Springer-Verlag London Limited 2010
label: paragraph

line: Doppelgangers
label: heading

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: Doppelganger is the term that we will use throughout this chapter to refer to virtual
label: paragraph

line: versions of the self. Doppelganger is derived from the German language and is defined
label: paragraph

line: as any double or look-alike of a person. Throughout history, several famous individuals
label: paragraph

line: have reported seeing their doppelganger. For example, in 1860 as the U.S. presidential
label: paragraph

line: election results were rolling in, Abraham Lincoln reported seeing two versions of him-
label: paragraph

line: self in the reflection of a long piece of glass – one version’s face much paler than the
label: paragraph

line: other. After sharing this encounter with his wife, she supposedly predicted that the
label: paragraph

line: image of the doppelganger signified that Abraham would be elected to a second term
label: paragraph

line: as president but that he would not survive the second term (Sandburg 1954).
label: paragraph

line: A loose definition of digital doppelgangers exists in online and video games. In
label: paragraph

line: the Massively Multiplayer Online games (MMOs), which are described in a number
label: paragraph

line: of chapters in this volume, players get to design the appearance of their avatar that
label: paragraph

line: moves through the 3D virtual game. In many of these games, there are very few
label: paragraph

line: constraints for avatar creation and with the drag of a slider bar players can control
label: paragraph

line: their identity – height, weight, age, and even species.
label: paragraph

line: We also see avatars in traditional console video games. For example, players of
label: paragraph

line: the Nintendo Wii can design a virtual representation (“mii”) that resembles them on
label: paragraph

line: many dimensions (Ratan et al. 2007). The Play Station skateboarding video game,
label: paragraph

line: Tony Hawk’s Underground 2 Remix, also allows players to personalize their avatars
label: paragraph

line: by uploading photographs of their own face to the game console (Lum 2005). After
label: paragraph

line: the photographs are mapped onto the face of a generic character, players can then
label: paragraph

line: control their virtual representation just as any other generic video game character.
label: paragraph

line: In the previous examples, users could create and control avatars that looked like
label: paragraph

line: them. However, in many cases, users are not in control of their look-alike avatars;
label: paragraph

line: sometimes other players or algorithms take control. This is the case in which avatars
label: paragraph

line: become doppelgangers. In the online video game World of Warcraft (Morhaime
label: paragraph

line: 2009), for example, players’ avatars can be “mind-controlled” by other players. In
label: paragraph

line: this situation, the player loses all control of his/her personal avatar and must watch
label: paragraph

line: for several seconds while his/her avatar is manipulated by another player – often
label: paragraph

line: with intentions of sabotage. We also see players’ avatars acting autonomously in
label: paragraph

line: some sports video games. In hockey and football games, the player can only control
label: paragraph

line: one player at a time. When a player relinquishes control of one avatar to take
label: paragraph

line: control of another, he/she passes the control of the first avatar to a computer algo-
label: paragraph

line: rithm. The avatar is still part of the player’s team, but is autonomously controlled.
label: paragraph

line: In another World of Warcraft example, some players possess pets that are semi-
label: paragraph

line: autonomous avatars. These pets mostly operate under the control of the player, but
label: paragraph

line: on occasion the pet will be sent on a mission where it must act autonomously. A com-
label: paragraph

line: puter algorithm guides the behavior of the pet during these missions while the
label: paragraph

line: player merely observes (not controls) the pet’s behavior. In sum, today’s video
label: paragraph

line: games allow for character building of characters, which look like the user, and also
label: paragraph

line: for algorithms to “take over” the behavior of the user.
label: paragraph

line: In the commercial world, digital doppelgangers can also be designed to
label: paragraph

line: look strikingly similar to the self. Through the use of digital photographs and
label: paragraph

line: 14 Virtual Doppelgangers: Psychological Effects of Avatars Who Ignore Their Owners 177
label: paragraph

line: Fig. 14.1 Images and modeling techniques used in creating three-dimensional heads
label: paragraph

line: head-modeling software, an individual’s visage may be replicated. In one commer-
label: paragraph

line: cial example, Bruce Willis created multiple versions of himself in the online game
label: paragraph

line: Second Life to advertise his movie Die Hard (Kingdon 2007). In a recent popcorn
label: paragraph

line: commercial, an ad agency created a virtual version of the late Orville Redenbacher
label: paragraph

line: using old photographs (Advertising Age 2007). The virtual Orville was then portrayed
label: paragraph

line: as wearing a slim, new MP3 player – something the real Orville Redenbacher mostly
label: paragraph

line: likely had never done in his lifetime.
label: paragraph

line: Scholars in the Virtual Human Interaction Lab at Stanford University have been
label: paragraph

line: using similar modeling techniques to create digital doppelgangers for research
label: paragraph

line: purposes for the past decade. Figure 14.1 depicts an example of how digital dop-
label: paragraph

line: pelgangers are developed from photographs (Bailenson et al. 2004, 2008). The top
label: paragraph

line: left panel shows two photographs of a person, and the bottom left shows the anchor
label: paragraph

line: points manually placed on the photographs with photogrammetric software. The
label: paragraph

line: right panel shows the resulting 3D head, which is a mesh model with a texture
label: paragraph

line: wrapped around it. Although this transference is not flawless, it creates relatively
label: paragraph

line: accurate models of the human form.
label: paragraph

line: Theoretical Underpinnings
label: heading

line: As doppelgangers that behave autonomously, that is, independent of the users they were
label: paragraph

line: modeled after, become increasingly present in new forms of media, scholars in the field
label: paragraph

line: need to leverage traditional psychological theories to understand how humans may
label: paragraph

line: be affected by the seemingly bizarre concept of being confronted by a virtual version
label: paragraph

line: of one’s self. Below, we outline several relevant theories from the past 50 years.
label: paragraph

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: Social cognitive theory, originally known as social learning theory, posits that
label: paragraph

line: people learn by observing the behavior of models (Bandura 1977, 2001). Several
label: paragraph

line: factors, including the similarity of the model, the observer’s perceived ability to
label: paragraph

line: perform the behavior, and the rewards and punishments associated with that behavior,
label: paragraph

line: predict the likelihood of the observer performing the modeled action. In the physical
label: paragraph

line: world, it can be quite difficult to find a model that fits all of these factors. However,
label: paragraph

line: using digital media we can utilize and manipulate virtual humans, even digital
label: paragraph

line: doppelgangers to successfully fulfill these criteria.
label: paragraph

line: Identification has been shown to increase the likelihood of performing learned
label: paragraph

line: behaviors (Bandura 2001; Bandura and Huston 1961). Observers must feel that the
label: paragraph

line: model is similar enough to them that they are able to experience the same out-
label: paragraph

line: comes. Similarity may be based on physical traits, personality variables, or shared
label: paragraph

line: beliefs and attitudes (Stotland 1969). Indeed, the likelihood of learning increases
label: paragraph

line: when models are of the same sex (Andsager et al. 2006), race (Ito et al. 2008), or
label: paragraph

line: skill level (Meichengaum 1971), as well as when models demonstrate similar opin-
label: paragraph

line: ions (Hilmert et al. 2006) or previous behaviors (Andsager et al. 2006).
label: paragraph

line: In creating digital doppelgangers, it goes without saying that social scientists
label: paragraph

line: produce models that possess a very high level of physical resemblance to their user.
label: paragraph

line: Digital doppelgangers are the richest possible model of the self that we have access
label: paragraph

line: to today, and thus they have great potential to serve as powerful models in Bandura’s
label: paragraph

line: social cognitive theory.
label: paragraph

line: Media richness theory, also known as information richness theory, was developed
label: paragraph

line: by Daft and Lengel (1984). In this theory, a medium’s richness is generally defined
label: paragraph

line: by its ability to reproduce the information sent over it. But more specifically, Daft,
label: paragraph

line: Lengel, and Trevino (1987) describe media richness based on four criteria: (1)
label: paragraph

line: capacity for immediate feedback, (2) capacity to transmit multiple cues such as
label: paragraph

line: graphic symbols or human gestures, (3) language variety, including numbers and
label: paragraph

line: natural language, and (4) capacity of the medium to have a personal focus.
label: paragraph

line: Under these criteria, doppelgangers in immersive virtual environments are very
label: paragraph

line: rich forms of media. Immersive virtual environment technology (IVET) offers
label: paragraph

line: dynamic user-specific viewpoints and a wider field of view than other forms of
label: paragraph

line: two-dimensional media (Blascovich et al. 2002). In addition, newer IVET systems
label: paragraph

line: are delivering more forms of perceptual detail. Audio technology is being used to
label: paragraph

line: produce three-dimensional sound; haptic devices permit virtual touch (Tan et al.
label: paragraph

line: 1994), a scent collar emits virtual scent (Nakamoto and Minh 2007), and a haptic
label: paragraph

line: interface puts pressure on the tongue to enhance virtual taste (Iwata et al. 2004).
label: paragraph

line: But regardless of whether a user is able to interact with his/her doppelganger in
label: paragraph

line: an immersive virtual environment, the personalized avatar is a rich form of media
label: paragraph

line: in its own right, as it maximizes more than any other existing medium, the “personal
label: paragraph

line: focus” parameter.
label: paragraph

line: The self-referential encoding (SRE) effect states that individuals learn and
label: paragraph

line: remember information better when it is related to the self. Rogers and colleagues
label: paragraph

line: (1977) proposed that information relating to the self would be remembered and
label: paragraph

line: learned better because it would be preferentially encoded and organized above
label: paragraph

line: other types of information. In fact, in the original experiment conducted in 1977,
label: paragraph

line: 14 Virtual Doppelgangers: Psychological Effects of Avatars Who Ignore Their Owners 179
label: paragraph

line: Rogers and colleagues found that adjectives were twice as likely to be recalled
label: paragraph

line: correctly when they were presented in a self-referential frame (Does this adjective
label: paragraph

line: describe you?) versus when they were presented in a semantic frame (Does
label: paragraph

line: this adjective mean the same as X?). Furthermore, Symons and Johnson (1997)
label: paragraph

line: conducted a meta-analysis involving 129 studies of self-referential encoding effects
label: paragraph

line: where they confirmed the expected SRE effect.
label: paragraph

line: In addition, recent functional magnetic resonance imaging work reveals that
label: paragraph

line: self-referential information may even be processed using unique structures in the
label: paragraph

line: human brain. Heatherton et al. (2004) found that the level of activity in the medial
label: paragraph

line: prefrontal cortex during self-referential judgments predicted which items would be
label: paragraph

line: remembered by the participant in a surprise memory test. Thus, not only does activity
label: paragraph

line: in certain regions of the brain track with self-referential processing, but this activity
label: paragraph

line: also contributes to the formation of self-referential memories.
label: paragraph

line: In consideration of the SRE effect literature, the human brain may preferentially
label: paragraph

line: process information that our doppelgangers convey to us over information that is
label: paragraph

line: presented to us via other humans/avatars. This is an especially important concept
label: paragraph

line: when it comes to considering autonomous doppelgangers, as the findings suggest
label: paragraph

line: that autonomous avatars that merely look like their users (even if they do not act
label: paragraph

line: like their user or share similar beliefs with their user) will activate preferential
label: paragraph

line: information encoding.
label: paragraph

line: Self-perception theory (SPT) was developed by psychologist Daryl Bem (1972).
label: paragraph

line: SPT posits that humans develop their attitudes by observing their own behavior and
label: paragraph

line: concluding what attitudes must have caused them. The theory is somewhat counter-
label: paragraph

line: intuitive in that common sense would tell us that attitudes come prior to behaviors,
label: paragraph

line: but many studies have produced data that support this theory. For example, several
label: paragraph

line: studies have shown that emotions can be derived from behaviors. Such emotions as
label: paragraph

line: liking, disliking, happiness, and anger were induced by overt behaviors that had
label: paragraph

line: been manipulated by research assistants (Larid 2007).
label: paragraph

line: For example, Frank and Gilovich (1988) conducted a study in which they found
label: paragraph

line: that participants who wore black uniforms behaved more aggressively than partici-
label: paragraph

line: pants in white uniforms. According to Frank and Gilovich, wearing a black uniform
label: paragraph

line: is a behavior that the participants used to infer their own dispositions – “Just as
label: paragraph

line: observers see those in black uniforms as tough, mean, and aggressive, so too does
label: paragraph

line: the person wearing that uniform” (1988: 83). The participants then adhere to this
label: paragraph

line: new identity by behaving more aggressively.
label: paragraph

line: Recently, similar effects have been replicated in digital environments. Merola and
label: paragraph

line: colleagues discovered that users given doppelgangers in a black robe expressed a
label: paragraph

line: higher desire to commit antisocial behaviors than users given doppelgangers in
label: paragraph

line: white robes (Merola et al. 2006). Nick Yee has taken such work one step further and
label: paragraph

line: developed a hypothesis that he terms the Proteus Effect (Yee and Bailenson 2007).
label: paragraph

line: The Proteus Effect predicts that an individual’s behavior conforms to their digital
label: paragraph

line: self-representation independent of how others perceive them. For example, subjects
label: paragraph

line: who occupy attractive (compared to unattractive or average attractive) avatars behave
label: paragraph

line: more socially, and taller avatars negotiate more confidently than shorter avatars.
label: paragraph

line: More surprisingly, the confidence from height and socialness from attractiveness
label: paragraph

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: extends outside the virtual world to subsequent face-to-face interactions (Yee et al.
label: paragraph

line: 2009; Yee and Bailenson Forthcoming). A recent study by Jung and colleagues in
label: paragraph

line: 2008 extended this work to show that the same pattern holds for gender; regardless
label: paragraph

line: of actual gender, participants embodied by male avatars gestured more masculinely
label: paragraph

line: than those in female avatars in terms of interpersonal distance (Jung and McLaughlin
label: paragraph

line: 2008). In sum, the self-referencing process does extend to avatars.
label: paragraph

line: Experimenting with Doppelgangers
label: heading

line: Now we turn to a number of recent experiments that have explored the question of
label: paragraph

line: what happens when individuals are exposed to their autonomous doppelgangers. As
label: paragraph

line: we see from the above sections, the notion of seeing oneself from the third person is
label: paragraph

line: possible with today’s digital media; moreover, existing psychological theory provides
label: paragraph

line: predictions for this line of work. We focus on three different research areas: health
label: paragraph

line: communication, marketing, and false memories. Figure 14.2 (Panels 2–5) provides
label: paragraph

line: screenshots of these various scenarios. Panel 1 on the left shows a participant wearing
label: paragraph

line: the head mounted display or HMD (A) where cameras (C) tracked the LED (B) on
label: paragraph

line: the user’s head to update the scene based on head rotations and translations.
label: paragraph

line: All experiments discussed were run at Stanford’s Virtual Human Interaction Lab,
label: paragraph

line: and the general research paradigm was similar for all studies reviewed. For an
label: paragraph

line: experimental “pretest,” all participants visited the lab well in advance of their experi-
label: paragraph

line: mental session, where research assistants photographed the front and profile of the
label: paragraph

line: participants’ faces. Then, research assistants produced three-dimensional models of
label: paragraph

line: each participant’s face. When the participants returned to the lab, they interacted
label: paragraph

line: Fig. 14.2 Images from each of the experimental studies
label: paragraph

line: 14 Virtual Doppelgangers: Psychological Effects of Avatars Who Ignore Their Owners 181
label: paragraph

line: with their digital doppelganger in a virtual environment. We then measured their
label: paragraph

line: behavioral, self-report, and memory reactions to their digital doppelganger.
label: paragraph

line: Social cognitive theory is often utilized to understand and design treatments and
label: paragraph

line: campaigns for health behavior change. IVET and digital doppelgangers enable novel
label: paragraph

line: explorations of health behavior modeling. Over the past three years, Jesse Fox
label: paragraph

line: has explored how humans might learn healthy behaviors from their doppelgangers.
label: paragraph

line: For example, in one study (Fox and Bailenson 2009), on arriving in the lab, partici-
label: paragraph

line: pants were taught a simple arm exercise. Once the participant had successfully
label: paragraph

line: learned the exercise, he/she was immersed into one of three virtual environments
label: paragraph

line: depending on condition (see Panel 2 of Fig. 14.2).
label: paragraph

line: Participants who were randomly assigned to the no doppelganger condition
label: paragraph

line: were immersed in an environment that portrayed a small room but no virtual
label: paragraph

line: human. Participants assigned to the changing doppelganger condition saw their
label: paragraph

line: doppelganger from the third person perspective just as participants who were ran-
label: paragraph

line: domly assigned to the unchanging doppelganger condition. However, the changing
label: paragraph

line: doppelganger was programmed to gradually gain weight while the participant idled
label: paragraph

line: and gradually lose weight while the participant exercised in the physical world.
label: paragraph

line: Participants in the unchanging doppelganger viewed a doppelganger that remained
label: paragraph

line: the same weight regardless of the participant’s behavior.
label: paragraph

line: In the virtual environment, participants were instructed to perform three sets of
label: paragraph

line: 12 arm exercises. Next, the experimenter instructed them to stand still for two minutes,
label: paragraph

line: and finally they were told they could stay in the virtual environment and exercise
label: paragraph

line: or could chose to end the experiment. The number of exercise repetitions that
label: paragraph

line: the participant completed in the voluntary phase were counted and recorded as the
label: paragraph

line: dependent variable.
label: paragraph

line: Data analysis revealed that participants in the changing doppelganger condition
label: paragraph

line: completed significantly more voluntary exercises than participants in either the
label: paragraph

line: unchanging doppelganger or no doppelganger conditions. These findings suggest that
label: paragraph

line: doppelgangers can show the rewards of exercise and can change behavior as a result.
label: paragraph

line: However, it could be the case that any demonstration of cause and effect could
label: paragraph

line: cause more exercise behavior (i.e., the virtual representation did not need to look
label: paragraph

line: like the self). In a follow-up study, Fox and Bailenson (2009) compared the effects
label: paragraph

line: of a doppelganger that looks like the self with a doppelganger of another person.
label: paragraph

line: They found that participants who viewed the doppelganger of the self exercised
label: paragraph

line: significantly more than those participants who saw the doppelganger of another
label: paragraph

line: person. Thus, there is evidence that self-identification is a driving factor behind
label: paragraph

line: the results.
label: paragraph

line: In the final study of the series (Fox and Bailenson 2009), participants were
label: paragraph

line: exposed to either a doppelganger of the self-running on a treadmill, a doppelganger
label: paragraph

line: of another running on a treadmill, or a doppelganger of the self-loitering. Instead of
label: paragraph

line: measuring exercise activity immediately following the treatment in the laboratory,
label: paragraph

line: participants in this study were asked 24 h later to reflect on their physical activity
label: paragraph

line: since the study and complete a standard questionnaire on physical activity. Data
label: paragraph

line: analysis revealed that participants in the doppelganger of the self condition performed
label: paragraph

line: significantly more exercise than participants in the other two conditions.
label: paragraph

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: In addition to exercise, Fox and colleagues also examined eating behavior (Fox
label: paragraph

line: et al. 2009). Participants saw their digital doppelgangers from a third-person per-
label: paragraph

line: spective eat either chocolate candy or baby carrots for a couple of minutes and then
label: paragraph

line: switch to eat from the other bowl of food, as depicted in Panel 3 of Fig. 14.2.
label: paragraph

line: After exiting the virtual environment, participants filled out several different
label: paragraph

line: questionnaires beside a bowl of chocolate candy. The participants were told that
label: paragraph

line: they could eat as many chocolates as they liked while they completed the surveys.
label: paragraph

line: Research assistants secretly recorded how many chocolates each participant ate. Of
label: paragraph

line: participants who were “high presence,” that is, were highly engaged in the simula-
label: paragraph

line: tion, males and females responded differently to the stimulus. Men displayed
label: paragraph

line: stereotypical gendered behavior and ate more candy, whereas women also displayed
label: paragraph

line: gendered behavior and suppressed the urge to eat and ate less candy.
label: paragraph

line: Self-endorsement, or advertisements that portray potential consumers using prod-
label: paragraph

line: ucts, is a novel marketing strategy of advertising made possible by digital doppel-
label: paragraph

line: gangers. Self-referential encoding effect has been used to explain the effects of
label: paragraph

line: self-endorsement. Ahn and Bailenson (2008) compared the effects of self-endorse-
label: paragraph

line: ment and unfamiliar other endorsement on the viewers of soft drink advertisements.
label: paragraph

line: In the study, two independent variables were manipulated and compared within the
label: paragraph

line: context of a soft drink advertisement. Identity served as the first independent variable
label: paragraph

line: with two values: self versus other. Medium served as the second independent variable with
label: paragraph

line: two values: photo versus text. Creating the photo self-endorsement stimulus involved
label: paragraph

line: replacing the celebrity or typical consumer endorser’s photograph in an online
label: paragraph

line: advertisement with a two-dimensional image of the self’s doppelganger. The photo
label: paragraph

line: other-endorsement stimulus was created by replacing the celebrity or typical consumer
label: paragraph

line: endorser’s photograph with a two-dimensional image of the doppelganger of an unfa-
label: paragraph

line: miliar same sex participant in the study, as depicted in Panel 4 of Fig. 14.2. The text
label: paragraph

line: self-endorsement was created by drafting a text ad that used the second person
label: paragraph

line: pronoun “you.” The same ad was used for the text other-endorsement condition, except
label: paragraph

line: that the second-person pronouns were changed to third-person pronouns.
label: paragraph

line: Each participant saw one soft drink ad that was representative of each of the four
label: paragraph

line: conditions: self-photo, self-text, other photo, other text. The main effect of identity
label: paragraph

line: was statistically significant. The self-endorsement condition evoked more positive
label: paragraph

line: ratings of the soft drinks than the other-endorsement condition. In addition, when
label: paragraph

line: participants were asked to report which soft drink they felt the highest level of
label: paragraph

line: association with, participants reported that they felt the greatest level of association
label: paragraph

line: with which ever soft drink was in the photo self-endorsement condition. These find-
label: paragraph

line: ings reveal that photo self-endorsement triggered the highest level of self-referencing
label: paragraph

line: when compared with all other conditions. In sum, doppelgangers are powerful
label: paragraph

line: marketing agents and can be used in advertisements to create favorable brand
label: paragraph

line: impressions among consumers.
label: paragraph

line: In a recent study (Segovia and Bailenson in press), the authors of this chapter
label: paragraph

line: explored how human memory could be affected by doppelgangers. We aimed to
label: paragraph

line: answer the question of whether doppelgangers could induce false memories in their
label: paragraph

line: users and hypothesized that rich media (such as doppelgangers) would be more
label: paragraph

line: likely to induce false memories than less rich media.
label: paragraph

line: 14 Virtual Doppelgangers: Psychological Effects of Avatars Who Ignore Their Owners 183
label: paragraph

line: Approximately 60 pre-school and elementary children visited the lab for two
label: paragraph

line: different sessions. In the first session, each child was introduced to a short narrative
label: paragraph

line: that described him/her participating in a completely fabricated and implausible
label: paragraph

line: event (i.e., swimming with two orca whales). The child was immediately questioned
label: paragraph

line: in the baseline interview about his/her memory of the event (i.e., Do you remember
label: paragraph

line: swimming with the orca whales?). Next, the child was exposed to one of four
label: paragraph

line: different memory prompt conditions: idle, mental imagery, doppelganger of another,
label: paragraph

line: doppelganger of self. In the idle condition, the child was instructed to sit and wait
label: paragraph

line: for a few minutes before the next interview. Children in the mental imagery condi-
label: paragraph

line: tion were instructed to imagine swimming with the whales for a few minutes.
label: paragraph

line: Children in the doppelganger conditions were immersed in a virtual reality environ-
label: paragraph

line: ment where they either saw another child swimming with the orca whales or a
label: paragraph

line: virtual representation of themselves swimming with the orca whales, respectively
label: paragraph

line: (Panel 5 of Fig. 14.2). Following the treatment, each child was questioned about
label: paragraph

line: his/her memory of the event. About 1 week later, all of the children returned to the
label: paragraph

line: lab to be interviewed one more time about their memory of the event.
label: paragraph

line: The children’s memories were coded based on their completeness ranging from
label: paragraph

line: no false memory to a complete false memory (where children actually recalled
label: paragraph

line: swimming with the orca whales in the physical world). Data analysis revealed that
label: paragraph

line: while the pre-school children were equally likely to form false memories across all
label: paragraph

line: memory prompt conditions, elementary children were more likely to form false
label: paragraph

line: memories in the mental imagery and doppelganger of the self-conditions when
label: paragraph

line: compared with the idle condition. These results give support to our claim that as the
label: paragraph

line: media richness of the prompt increases, the more difficult it becomes to distinguish
label: paragraph

line: between an actual memory elicited by a physical world event and a false memory
label: paragraph

line: elicited by mental image or doppelganger.
label: paragraph

line: We believe that these results are uniquely interesting because they reveal that
label: paragraph

line: mental imagery (which must be actively initiated by the participant) and IVET dop-
label: paragraph

line: pelganger of the self-simulations (which can be completely controlled by a third
label: paragraph

line: party) are both powerful in eliciting false memories in children. In other words, by
label: paragraph

line: viewing an IVET simulation of the self, a passive observer can develop false memo-
label: paragraph

line: ries just as easily as a participant using cognitive energy to create mental images.
label: paragraph

line: This finding suggests that third parties may be able to elicit false memories without
label: paragraph

line: the consent or mental effort of an individual.
label: paragraph

line: Implications and Future Directions
label: heading

line: Research on doppelgangers, especially autonomous doppelgangers, highlights
label: paragraph

line: several ethical considerations. As can be seen in the Orville Redenbacher example,
label: paragraph

line: it is possible for one’s digital doppelganger to exist (and be manipulated) long after
label: paragraph

line: the physical self has died. One provocative question that arises is who should
label: paragraph

line: possess ownership of digital doppelgangers and to what extent are manipulations
label: paragraph

line: ethically acceptable? Currently, the artists who construct doppelgangers have
label: paragraph

line: J.N. Bailenson and K.Y. Segovia
label: paragraph

line: nearly unlimited freedom in what animations and edits they create. In the future,
label: paragraph

line: some celebrities may wish to add clauses to their legal contracts that forbid or at
label: paragraph

line: least restrict the development of digital doppelgangers. On the other hand, other
label: paragraph

line: individuals may wish to encourage the development and distribution of their digital
label: paragraph

line: doppelgangers in order to further their legacy.
label: paragraph

line: Digital doppelgangers have many practical applications in social psychology and
label: paragraph

line: education. For example, digital doppelgangers and IVET may be powerful tools for
label: paragraph

line: teaching individuals about the negative impact of their carbon footprints. First, using
label: paragraph

line: digital doppelgangers, experimenters and educators can use digital representations
label: paragraph

line: of the student to serve as the model. Because of high levels of similarity with the
label: paragraph

line: student, digital doppelgangers (as we have shown above) are powerful models.
label: paragraph

line: Second, using IVET and digital doppelgangers, educators and researchers can ben-
label: paragraph

line: efit from the ability to transform space, time, and physical laws. Climate change
label: paragraph

line: literacy studies would examine the benefits of compressing time to show cumulative
label: paragraph

line: environmental damage or making carbon footprints of supermarket products visible.
label: paragraph

line: Climate change education is one example, but IVET and digital doppelgangers may
label: paragraph

line: be effective tools for educators and social scientists in other topic areas as well.
label: paragraph

line: Autonomous digital doppelgangers are a theoretically and ethically interesting
label: paragraph

line: concept. As new media continue to develop and become more personalized, we
label: paragraph

line: may face digital doppelganger issues more frequently. These digital representations
label: paragraph

line: will help us refine psychological theories and pose interesting questions in their
label: paragraph

line: own right.
label: paragraph

line: Acknowledgments The authors thank Sun Joo Ahn, Jesse Fox, James Scarborough, and Nick
label: paragraph

line: Yee for their helpful comments on this chapter. The current work was partially supported by
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: supported Kathryn Segovia during her contribution to this research.
